story.text: Jan 2 The following were the top stories in The Wall Street Journal on Tuesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy. * The U.S. economy is poised to shake off the housing slump and regain momentum by year's end, according to a Wall Street Journal survey of economists. * The largest U.S. airlines are ready to report their first annual profits since 2000, and 2007 results could be even stronger. * Investors approach 2007 optimistic as the U.S. Federal Reserve seems to be done raising rates and the economy so far is out of a recession. But skeptics think the bullishness goes too far. * AT&T Inc. (T.N) will aggressively push new wireless services and make advertising a key revenue stream, Chief Executive Officer Edward Whitacre said. * General Motors Corp. (GM.N) is unveiling a revamped look for its 2008 Malibu, trying to generate as much early buzz as possible for the sedan, in part to build investor confidence in its turnaround strategy. * Two former Apple Computer Inc. (AAPL.O) executives, Fred Anderson and Nancy Heinen, are in the spotlight amid options-backdating probes. * A world-wide liquidity boom has boosted shares and fueled mergers but is sometimes distorting financial markets. * Sony BMG and Rock River struck a deal to license songs for promotional podcasts on behalf of corporate clients. * Online video is being adopted for corporate communications chores by a growing number of large nonmedia businesses. * Steelmakers are finding that their expansion plans in India are hampered by bureaucracy and poor infrastructure.
story.title: press digest - wall street journal - jan 2
